nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a robust e-commerce platform that offers a variety of features and functionalities to setup Magento 2 and managing an it. nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a robust e-commerce platform that offers a variety of features and functionalities to setup Magento 2 and managing an it. One of the essential elements of an online store is the robots.txt file, which plays a crucial role in directing search engines on how to crawl and index the site’s pages. The robots.txt file is a simple text file that resides in the root directory of a website and informs search engine bots which pages or sections of the site should not be crawled or indexed.In this blog post, we’ll explain how to configure the robots.txt file in Magento 2.

Steps to Configure robots.txt File in Magento 2

Step 1: Access the Magento 2 Admin Panel

To start, log in to your Magento 2 admin panel.

Step 2: Navigate to the Store Configuration

In the Magento 2 Admin Panel, click on the “Stores” tab and then click on “Configuration.”

Step 3: Go to the Search Engine Robots Section

Under the “General” tab, click on the “Design” option. Then, expand the “Search Engine Robots” section.

Step 4: Edit the Robots.txt File

In the “Search Engine Robots” section, you can edit the robots.txt file directly in the text editor. You can add or remove rules as needed.

Step 5: Save the Changes

Once you have made the necessary changes, click on the “Save Config” button to save your changes.

Step 6: Verify the Changes

To verify the changes, you can use a tool like the robots.txt checker to see if the changes have been implemented correctly.

Conclusion

In conclusion, having a properly configured robots.txt file is critical for the success of your online store. It helps you control how search engines crawl your website, which in turn affects your website’s visibility and search engine ranking. With the steps outlined in this blog, you can easily configure the robots.txt file in Magento 2 and ensure that search engines are indexing your website correctly. Remember to always verify the changes made to the robots.txt file and to have a clear understanding of its purpose before making any modifications.

nodes.title: How to Programmatically Get All Websites in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a robust and flexible e-commerce platform that provides a wide range of features and tools for developers to create and manage online stores. As a developer, you may need to retrieve a list of all websites in Magento 2 for various purposes, such as assigning categories, updating website settings, or creating new … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a robust and flexible e-commerce platform that provides a wide range of features and tools for developers to create and manage online stores. As a developer, you may need to retrieve a list of all websites in Magento 2 for various purposes, such as assigning categories, updating website settings, or creating new stores. In this blog, we will dive into the details of how to programmatically get all websites in Magento 2. We will be using the Magento\Store\Model\StoreManagerInterface class, which is a built-in class in Magento 2 that provides access to all store-related data and functionality. This class enables us to retrieve a list of all websites available in the Magento installation and perform various operations on them. By the end of this blog, you will have a clear understanding of how to programmatically get all websites in Magento 2. Additionally, you may also want to know how to install an extension manually in Magento 2, which is a useful skill for developers to have.

Prerequisites

1. Magento 2 installed and running

2. Basic knowledge of Magento 2 development

Steps to programmatically get all websites in Magento 2

Step 1: Create a module

To start, we need to create a module in Magento 2. You can create a module using the following steps:

– Create a folder with the name of your module in app/code.

– Create etc, Controller, Model and view folders in your module folder.

– Create a registration.php file in your module folder with the following code:

php

\Magento\Framework\Component\ComponentRegistrar::register(

    \Magento\Framework\Component\ComponentRegistrar::MODULE,

    'Vendor_ModuleName',

    __DIR__

);

- Create a module.xml file in etc folder with the following code:

lua

<config xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="urn:magento:framework:Module/etc/module.xsd">

    <module name="Vendor_ModuleName" setup_version="1.0.0">

    </module>

</config>

Replace Vendor and ModuleName with your vendor and module name.

Step 2: Get a list of all websites

To get a list of all websites in Magento 2, we need to use the Magento\Store\Model\StoreManagerInterface class.

Add the following code to your controller file:

php

<?php

namespace Vendor\ModuleName\Controller;

use Magento\Framework\App\Action\Action;

use Magento\Framework\App\Action\Context;

use Magento\Store\Model\StoreManagerInterface;

class Index extends Action

{

    /**

     * @var StoreManagerInterface

     */

    private $storeManager;

    /**

     * Index constructor.

     * @param Context $context

     * @param StoreManagerInterface $storeManager

     */

    public function __construct(

        Context $context,

        StoreManagerInterface $storeManager

    ) {

        $this->storeManager = $storeManager;

        parent::__construct($context);

    }

    /**

     * Get all websites

     *

     * @return void

     */

    public function execute()

    {

        $websites = $this->storeManager->getWebsites();

        foreach ($websites as $website) {

            echo $website->getName().' (ID: '.$website->getId().')<br>';

        }

    }

}

Step 3: Test

Now, run the following URL in your browser to test your code:

perl

http://your-magento-base-url/module-name/index/index

Replace your-magento-base-url and module-name with your Magento base URL and module name.

Conclusion 

In this blog, we learned how to programmatically get all websites in Magento 2 using the Store Manager Interface class. This method is useful for developers who need to manipulate website data in Magento 2. You can use the retrieved websites data to perform various operations such as creating new stores, assigning categories, and updating website settings. With the knowledge of how to programmatically get all websites in Magento 2, you can take your e-commerce development to the next level.

nodes.title: How to Use a Custom Price Template in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that provides a range of features and customization options to store owners. One such customization is the ability to create a custom price template. In this blog, we’ll provide a step-by-step guide on how to use a custom price template in Magento 2. With a custom price template, … Read more
nodes.content:
Magento 2 is a popular e-commerce platform that provides a range of features and customization options to store owners. One such customization is the ability to create a custom price template. In this blog, we’ll provide a step-by-step guide on how to use a custom price template in Magento 2. With a custom price template, store owners can showcase product prices in a manner that aligns with their store’s overall design, brand image, and pricing strategy, including the display of tier prices.

What is custom price

Custom Price is a feature in e-commerce platforms like Magento 2 that allows store owners to display product prices in a custom manner, rather than using the default price template provided by the platform. Custom prices can be designed to match a store’s overall design, brand image, and pricing strategy. With a custom price template, store owners have greater control over the way prices are displayed on their store, allowing them to provide a more seamless and personalized shopping experience for their customers.

What is custom price Template 

A Custom Price Template is a template file used to customize the way prices are displayed on an e-commerce website. In Magento 2, a custom price template can be created by store owners to display product prices in a way that matches the overall design, brand image, and pricing strategy of their store. The custom price template is a .phtml file that contains HTML code to define the layout and style of the price display. Store owners can add the custom price template to the product page by updating the layout file and specifying the location of the custom price template file. Using a custom price template allows store owners to enhance the look and feel of their store, providing a more personalized and seamless shopping experience for their customers.

Step 1: Create the custom price template

To create a custom price template in Magento 2, you need to first create a new module. You can do this by creating a new directory in the app/code directory with the name of your module and then creating the necessary files. The files you need to create are: registration.php, module.xml, and composer.json.

Step 2: Define the custom price template

Once you’ve created the new module, you need to define the custom price template. To do this, you’ll need to create a new .phtml file in the app/code/[ModuleName]/view/frontend/templates directory. This file should contain the HTML code for your custom price template.

Step 3: Add the custom price template to the product page

To add the custom price template to the product page, you need to update the layout file for the product page. To do this, you’ll need to create a new layout file in the app/code/[ModuleName]/view/frontend/layout directory. This layout file should contain the following code:

php

<referenceBlock name="product.price.render.default">

    <arguments>

        <argument name="price_template" xsi:type="string">[ModuleName]_[ModuleName]::price/[CustomPriceTemplate].phtml</argument>

    </arguments>

</referenceBlock>

Step 4: Test the custom price template

Once you’ve completed the above steps, you should test your custom price template to ensure that it’s working as expected. To do this, simply navigate to a product page on your Magento 2 store and check the price display.

Conclusion

In conclusion, using a custom price template in Magento 2 is a simple process that can greatly enhance the look and feel of your store. By following the steps outlined in this blog, you can create a custom price template that fits your store’s design and brand image. Additionally, with a custom price template, you can improve the overall shopping experience for your customers, helping to increase customer loyalty and drive sales. Whether you’re a new or experienced Magento 2 store owner, using a custom price template is an excellent way to enhance your store’s appearance and functionality.

nodes.title: How to Combine Javascript files in Magento 2
nodes.excerpt: Combining Javascript files is a widely adopted practice to speed up page loading by reducing the number of HTTP requests required to bring Javascripts to your pages. By having all JS files combined, you only need to load one combined file instead of multiple separate javascript modules. How to combine Javascript files in Magento 2: … Read more
nodes.content:
Combining Javascript files is a widely adopted practice to speed up page loading by reducing the number of HTTP requests required to bring Javascripts to your pages.

By having all JS files combined, you only need to load one combined file instead of multiple separate javascript modules.

How to combine Javascript files in Magento 2: There are two methods to combine Javascript modules.

How to Combine Javascript Files in Magento 2: A Comprehensive Guide

Merging Javascripts

Simplifying the Combination of JS Files in Magento 2: The Merging Technique

The easiest way to combine all your JS files is by using the merging technique, which combines all the files into one large file. Here’s how to do it:

1.Log into the Magento 2 Backend and go to Stores → Configuration → Advanced → Developer.

2. Switch to the desired Storeview using the switcher on the top ribbon, if necessary. Merging can be enabled separately for each store.

3. Expand the Javascript Settings section and enable the option to Merge JavaScript Files.

4. If you want to make the combined JS file smaller, enable the option to Minify JavaScript Files. This will make Magento 2 remove formatting, spacing, and other non-significant parts of the combined scripts.

5. Go to System → Cache Management, scroll to the Advanced Cache Management section, and press the Flush Javascript/CSS Cache button.

6. Then, consecutively press the Flush Magento Cache and Flush Cache Storage buttons on the top ribbon.

7. Regenerate the static content using the Flush Static Files Cache button in the Advanced Cache Management section.

This will result in all Javascript on all pages being combined into one large file. However, this may not be enough. Merging only combines files loaded via layouts, i.e., files that are present on every page. For on-demand Javascript loaded via the internal Magento 2 RequireJS engine, you need to use bunding as well. Before performing these steps, it is important to enable Magento 2 developer mode.

Bundling Javascript

Combining On-Demand JS Files in Magento 2: The Bundling Technique

Magento 2 Javascript bundling is an important aspect of optimizing website performance. By combining Javascript files, you can reduce the number of HTTP requests and improve page loading speed. However, it’s essential to understand how Javascript bundling works in Magento 2, particularly in the context of the RequireJS engine. RequireJS is a modern JS loading engine that allows developers to restrict JS files to only load on specific pages. As a result, if you merge all your JS files into one combined file, it may not actually improve your website’s performance because RequireJS loads the files asynchronously, only when they are needed. Understanding the intricacies of Javascript bundling in Magento 2 is crucial for ensuring that your website performs optimally. In this article, we’ll explore how to combine Javascript files in Magento 2 while taking into account the role of RequireJS.

This is where bundling comes in. When enabled, Magento 2 combines all RequireJS modules on-the-fly when the page is being rendered. Here’s how to enable bundling:

  • Log in to the Magento 2 Backend and go to Stores → Configuration → Advanced → Developer.
  • Switch to the desired Storeview using the switcher on the top ribbon, if necessary. Bundling can also be enabled separately for each store.
  • Expand the JS Settings section and enable the option to Enable JavaScript Bundling.
  • Go to System → Cache Management, scroll to the Advanced Cache Management section, and press the Flush Javascript/CSS Cache button.
  • Then, consecutively press the Flush Magento Cache and Flush Cache Storage buttons on the top ribbon.
  • Regenerate the static content using the Flush Static Files Cache button in the Advanced Cache Management section.
  • Unlike merging, bundling allows you to exclude Javascript modules from being combined. This is very useful when using modules with JS conflicts in combined mode.

Excluding Javascript Modules from Bundling in Magento 2

To exclude specific Javascript modules from the bundling process:

  • Log in to your store’s FTP/SSH and go to the root of your store.
  • Go to your theme directory (for example, the Luma theme is located at Magento root/vendor/Magento/theme-frontend-luma) and navigate to its, etc subdirectory.
  • Open the view.xml file and locate the line <vars module=”Js_Bundle”>.
  • Under this line, add the Javascript modules you want to exclude to the <exclude> block using the same naming as in the RequireJS loading directives.

You can also adjust the bundle size of the dynamically created bundle by adjusting the bundle_size property.

Conclusion

In conclusion, installing modules manually in Magento 2 is a straightforward process that can greatly enhance your store’s functionality. If you’re looking to improve the performance of your Magento 2 website, combining Javascript files is a key step. By doing so, you can reduce the number of HTTP requests and improve page loading speed. When it comes to merging JS files, you can load a single large file instead of multiple separate modules, which can help optimize your website’s performance. However, it’s important to note that bundling is also necessary for files loaded via the RequireJS engine. By excluding certain JS modules from bundling, you can prevent conflicts and ensure that your website runs smoothly. By following the steps outlined in this guide on how to combine Javascript files in Magento 2, you can easily install modules and optimize your website’s performance.

nodes.title: How to enable Magento 2 Developer Mode
nodes.excerpt: Developer Mode in Magento 2 is a special mode designed to enhance development and debugging in your store. This mode offers various convenient features such as verbose logging, automatic code compilation, improved debugging tools, and the display of custom HTTP headers. If you’re looking to enable Developer Mode, you have two options: via the command … Read more
nodes.content:
Developer Mode in Magento 2 is a special mode designed to enhance development and debugging in your store. This mode offers various convenient features such as verbose logging, automatic code compilation, improved debugging tools, and the display of custom HTTP headers. If you’re looking to enable Developer Mode, you have two options: via the command line interface (CLI) or through the .htaccess file. Activating Developer Mode is a simple and easy process, and you can opt for the approach that suits you best. In this article, we’ll guide you through both methods of enabling Developer Mode in it. So, let’s get started with How to enable Magento 2 Developer Mode. After enabling Developer Mode, all its features will be accessible to you, which will make development and debugging more efficient and less complicated. Therefore, if you are seeking to enhance your development skills, discover how to activate Developer Mode in Magento 2 today. Here is a detailed guide on the steps for enabling Developer Mode through both the CLI and .htaccess methods, allowing you to pick the method that is most suitable for your particular setup.

How to Enable Magento 2 Developer Mode: A Comprehensive Guide

If you’re working with Magento 2 and need to troubleshoot issues in your store, it’s essential to know how to enable developer mode in Magento 2. To do so, you’ll first need to log in to your Magento 2 store’s root directory via SSH or terminal. Once you’re in the root directory, run the command “php bin/magento deploy:mode: set developer” to set your store to developer mode. You can then verify the mode is set by running the command “php bin/magento deploy:mode: show”.

After following the steps to enable Magento 2 Developer Mode via the command line interface (CLI), you can verify that the mode is set by running the command “php bin/magento deploy:mode: show”. This will display the current mode, which should now be “developer”. It’s important to note that this command won’t work if you’re using the .htaccess file to enable Developer Mode.

After enabling Developer Mode, it’s also crucial to clear the cache by running the command “php bin/magento cache: flush” to ensure that the changes take effect. With Developer Mode enabled, you’ll be able to access more detailed error messages, logs, and other debugging tools to help you identify and resolve issues quickly and efficiently. So, that’s How to enable Magento 2 Developer Mode and get the most out of Magento 2’s development and debugging features.

Magento 2’s Developer Mode enhances debugging and development by offering various convenient features. These include:

  • Verbose and customizable logging
  • Automatic code compilation
  • Improved debugging tools
  • Display of custom HTTP request and response headers (X-Magento-*)

Switching via SSH/CLI

The recommended and secure method to enable developer mode Magento 2 is by using the command line interface (CLI). Follow these steps:

  • Log in to your store via SSH/CLI and go to the root directory.
  • Clear generated classes and other data by running: rm -rf var/di/* var/generation/*
  • Activate Developer Mode using the command: bin/magento deploy:mode: set developer
  • Upon successful activation, you will receive a log message confirming the switch: Switched to developer mode

Activating Developer Mode through .htaccess

If access to your store via SSH/CLI is restricted, you can still activate Developer Mode by using an environment variable. Here’s how:

  • Log in to your store and go to the root directory.
  • Clear the contents of the var/di and var/generation directories.
  • Edit the .htaccess file.
  • Add the following line, typically at the beginning: SetEnv MAGE_MODE developer, This will force it to run in Developer Mode.

There are also other Two Magento 2 Modes Default mode and Production mode. Each mode has its own purpose and configuration settings, and they provide different levels of debugging and performance optimization.

Conclusion

In conclusion, knowing how to enable Magento 2 Developer Mode is crucial for enhancing your development and debugging experience. You can activate Developer Mode through the command line interface (CLI) or the .htaccess file in a few simple steps. By enabling Developer Mode, you’ll unlock a range of features that make development and debugging easier, such as verbose logging, automatic code compilation, improved debugging tools, and the display of custom HTTP headers. Whether you’re a developer or a store owner, enabling Developer Mode can help you identify and resolve issues in your store more efficiently. So, if you haven’t already, take the time to enable Developer Mode and unlock the full potential of your store.

So if you’re looking to optimize your development work, be sure to enable Developer Mode and take advantage of its many benefits. Also, don’t forget to learn How to Install Modules Manually in Magento 2 to further enhance your Magento 2 development experience.

nodes.excerpt: How to work with URL Rewrite functionality in Magento 2: A Guide to Online Store URL Customization. Online stores, including those based on Magento, may occasionally undergo changes, such as updates to item pages or indexes. A store rebuild could also result in the loss of clients if the URL of the pages are not … Read more
nodes.content:
How to work with URL Rewrite functionality in Magento 2: A Guide to Online Store URL Customization. Online stores, including those based on Magento, may occasionally undergo changes, such as updates to item pages or indexes. A store rebuild could also result in the loss of clients if the URL of the pages are not updated, as they may lead to non-existent pages. Magento 2’s URL Rewrite functionality provides a powerful way for store owners to modify specific URLs during store changes, making the existing URLs more search engine friendly and easier for users to understand. To enhance the store’s SEO, the administrator must revise the URLs to include keywords with higher SEO value. A well-crafted URL can improve the store’s ranking in search engine results pages (SERP). This guide will show you how to work with URL Rewrite functionality in Magento 2, which includes creating custom URL rewrites for your products, categories, and pages. With Magento 2’s URL Rewrite functionality, you can easily migrate to a new platform or update your website’s structure while ensuring that your URLs remain search engine and user-friendly. By enabling Web Server Apache Rewrites in the Search Engine Optimization section under the Web option in the Configuration menu, you can eliminate the “index.php” portion from the URL, making it even more readable and SEO-friendly.

How to Work with URL Rewrite Functionality in Magento 2: A Comprehensive Guide

The URL Rewrite tools

The Magento 2 URL Rewrite tool allows you to modify any URL linked to a product, category, or CMS page. Once the URL rewrite is implemented, all references to the previous URL will automatically redirect to the updated address.

Single URL rewrite 

Maximizing Your Online Store’s SEO with Magento 2 URL Rewrite:

The Magento 2 URL Rewrite tool is a powerful feature that enables you to create rewrites for products, categories, and any page within your store. This functionality provides a way to change the URL of a page without losing any SEO value or causing any interruptions. By using the Magento 2 URL Rewrite tool, you can easily rewrite URLs for your products, categories, and pages. This tool is particularly useful for eCommerce stores that need to make changes to their website structure or migrate to a new platform. Additionally, URL rewrites can be utilized to improve the way search engines index your products by adding high-value keywords, making it easier for customers to find your products. They can also be used for temporary or permanent URL changes, including CMS pages. The ID of a product or category remains constant, even if the URL changes, which ensures that the product or category will remain accessible and won’t lose any rankings. By following the steps outlined in this guide on How to Rewrite URL in Magento 2, you can easily create rewrites for your products, categories, and pages, ensuring that your website remains user-friendly and SEO-optimized.

Here are some examples of URL rewrites:

System URL: http://www.example.com/catalog/category/id/1

Original URL: http://www.example.com/category-name/page-name.html

Redirected Product URL: http://www.example.com/new-product-url.html

Magento 2 offers these types of URL rewrites:

  • Product Rewrites
  • Category Rewrites
  • CMS Page Rewrites
  • Custom Rewrites.

To quickly update URL rewrites for multiple or all products, follow these steps:

1. Go to Catalog > Products on the Admin sidebar.

2. Select the products for URL rewrites update.

3. Under Actions, select Update attributes.

4. Go to the Websites tab under PRODUCTS INFORMATION.

5. In Add Product To Websites, select the websites for URL rewrites restoration.

6. Click Save to update.

This will re-add the selected products to the selected websites and regenerate the URL rewrites.

The terms “redirection” and “rewrite” are often used interchangeably, but they refer to slightly different things. A rewrite refers to a change in how the URL is displayed to the visitor. Redirection is used when the URL on the server needs to be updated and can be either temporary or permanent.

URL redirections can be used in conjunction with rewrites to simplify editing the URL key of an item, category, or page and preserve existing URL links.

Stores using Adobe’s eCommerce framework can be set up to automatically create a permanent redirection whenever the URL key of an item or category changes. The store manager can configure redirection in the Search Engine Optimization section by checking the box under the URL key. This option indicates if permanent redirections are enabled.

If the store is already set up to automatically redirect list URLs to other addresses, creating a redirection is as simple as updating the URL key. The process is similar for items and categories.

When automatic redirects are enabled, the item category setup is saved, and all rewrites for items and categories are generated immediately and usually stored in database tables. This can result in significant performance issues for item categories that consist of many items.

Such performance problems can be solved by changing the default setup and avoiding rewriting the URLs for categories and items when the category setup is saved. In this case, rewrites for item URLs are created only for the standard item URL.

Setting up Automated Redirections:

1. Go to Stores > Settings > Configuration on the Admin sidebar.

2. In the left panel, expand Catalog and select it.

3. Expand the Search Engine Optimization section in the Expansion selector.

4. Change the setting for Create Permanent Redirect for URLs if the URL Key is Changed to Yes.

5. Click Save Config to finish.

Automating Product URL Redirection:

1. Go to Catalog > Products on the Admin sidebar.

2. Find the product in the list and click to open its record.

3. Expand the Search Engine Optimization section in the Expansion selector.

4. For the URL Key field: Ensure that the “Create Permanent Redirect for old URL” checkbox is selected. Update the URL Key as needed, using all lowercase letters and hyphens instead of spaces.

5. Click Save to confirm changes.

6. Follow the links in the cache refresh message at the top of the workspace when prompted. The permanent redirect is now active for the product and any related category URLs.

Turn off automatic generation of category/product URL rewrites with caution: disabling this feature will delete all existing category/product URL rewrites and cannot be undone. This may lead to URL conflicts that must be fixed manually by updating the URL key.

To turn off URL rewriting:

  • Go to Stores > Settings > Configuration on the Admin sidebar

           Under Catalog, select Catalog in the left panel

  • In the Search Engine Optimization section, expand the Generate “category/product” URL Rewrites field
  • Uncheck the Use system value checkbox and set the value to No
  • Confirm the change and deletion of existing URL rewrites in the confirmation dialog
  • Finally, click Save Config.

Note – Enabling automatic redirects will cause all product and category rewrite to be generated and stored in real-time whenever a category is saved. This could greatly impact performance for categories with many assigned products.

To resolve this issue, consider skipping the generation of category/product URL rewrites during category saves. In this case, only the canonical product URL will have product rewrites generated. For more information, see Automatic Product Redirects. Note that for security reasons, any GET parameters specified in the URL will be removed during the redirection process.

Setting up URL Rewrites

URL rewrites improve the readability and search engine optimization of existing URLs. Web Server Apache Rewrites are enabled as part of the Commerce setup process, and configuring them correctly can significantly improve your website’s SEO. In Magento 2, you can easily configure URL rewrites by enabling Web Server Apache Rewrites in the Search Engine Optimization section under the Web option in the Configuration menu. This eliminates the file name “index.php” from the URL, making it more readable and SEO-friendly. When Web Server Rewrites are enabled, the system automatically rewrites each URL to remove the “index.php” portion, which enhances the SEO and user experience by removing unnecessary words from the URL. This process does not affect performance or site ranking and can greatly improve your website’s visibility in search engine results pages (SERP). By following the steps outlined in this guide on How to Configure URL Rewrites in Magento 2, you can easily enable Web Server Apache Rewrites and improve your website’s SEO performance.

Example without Web Server Rewrite: 

http://www.yourdomain.com/magento/index.php/storeview/url-identifier

Example with Web Server Rewrite: http://www.yourdomain.com/magento/storeview/url-identifier

Configuring URL rewrites

  • Go to Stores > Settings > Configuration on the Admin sidebar

           In the left panel, under General, select Web

  • In the Search Engine Optimization section, find Use Web Server Rewrites
  • Set it to your desired setting
  • Click Save Config to save your changes.

In conclusion, configuring URL rewrites and adding Canonical tags are important steps in optimizing your website for search engines and improving the user experience in Magento 2. By enabling Web Server Apache Rewrites in the Search Engine Optimization section under the Web option in the Configuration menu, you can eliminate the “index.php” portion from the URL, making it more readable and search engine friendly. This is just one way to work with URL rewrite functionality in Magento 2. In fact, Magento 2 offers a powerful suite of tools for managing your website’s URLs, including the ability to create custom URL rewrites for your products, categories, and pages. The process of setting up URL rewrites is straightforward and can be done quickly by following the steps outlined in this guide on How to Work with URL Rewrite Functionality in Magento 2. Similarly, adding Canonical tags helps search engines understand which page is the preferred version of a set of pages with similar content. These techniques combined can help boost your website’s visibility and ranking. Overall, optimizing your website’s URLs is an important part of SEO, and Magento 2 provides the tools you need to do it effectively.

nodes.excerpt: If the administrator of an e-commerce store using Magento 2 accidentally loses access to their admin user account or gets locked out of the backend, it can be challenging to regain control. Magento 2 offers several features and customization options for online stores, but sometimes, unlocking the admin user is necessary. This blog will guide … Read more
nodes.content:
If the administrator of an e-commerce store using Magento 2 accidentally loses access to their admin user account or gets locked out of the backend, it can be challenging to regain control. Magento 2 offers several features and customization options for online stores, but sometimes, unlocking the admin user is necessary. This blog will guide you on how to unlock admin user in Magento 2 by accessing the database, locating the user record, updating the user status, clearing the cache, and logging back into the backend.

Steps to Unlock Admin User in Magento 2

Step 1: Access the Database

The first step in unlocking an admin user in Magento 2 is to access the database. You can do this using the following command in your terminal or command prompt:

css
mysql -u [database_username] -p[database_password] [database_name]

Replace [database_username], [database_password], and [database_name] with the credentials for your Magento 2 database.

Step 2: Find the User Record

Once you have accessed the database, you will need to find the record for the admin user account that you want to unlock. You can do this using the following SQL command:

sql
SELECT * FROM `admin_user` WHERE `username`='[admin_username]';

Replace [admin_username] with the username for the admin user account that you want to unlock.

Step 3: Update the User Status

Once you have located the user record, you will need to update the user status to unlock the account. You can do this using the following SQL command:

go
UPDATE `admin_user` SET `is_active` = '1' WHERE `username`='[admin_username]';

Replace [admin_username] with the username for the admin user account that you want to unlock.

Step 4: Clear the Cache

After updating the user status, it is important to clear the Magento 2 cache. You can do this using the following command:

bash
php bin/magento cache:clean

Step 5: Log in to the Backend

With the admin user account unlocked and the cache cleared, you should now be able to log in to the Magento 2 backend using the unlocked admin user account.

Conclusion

In conclusion, unlocking an admin user in Magento 2 is a straightforward process that can be completed in a few simple steps. By accessing the Magento 2 database, finding the user record, updating the user status, clearing the cache, and logging in to the backend, you can regain access to your admin user account.By having the knowledge of how to unlock an admin user, you can quickly regain access to your admin account in case of any unexpected lockouts or access issues. It is important to keep the database and user records updated to avoid such situations in the future. nodes.content:
The success of an e-commerce store is dependent on various factors, with traffic being a major one. It’s crucial for store owners to track and monitor their store traffic, and Google Analytics provides a free solution to do so. With this service, store owners can monitor traffic and conversion rates, and evaluate user engagement on every page to improve Magento SEO. If you’re wondering how to add Google Analytics code to Magento 2, how to add Google Analytics code in Magento 2, or even how to set up Google Analytics 4 Magento 2, you’re in the right place. This article will guide you through the process of adding Google Analytics code to your Magento 2 store.

Boost Your E-Commerce Insights: How to Add Google Analytics Code to Magento 2 with This Step-by-Step Guide

Step 1: Create a Google Analytics Account

  • Log in to your Gmail account and search for Google Analytics.
  • Click on Analytics from the top corner of the page.
  • Click on Sign Up.
  • Enter the details of your store (Account Name, Website Name, and Website URL) and click on Get Tracking ID.
  • Read the Google Analytics Terms of Service Agreement and click on I Accept.

Note – If you’re currently using Universal Analytics to track your Magento 2 store traffic, it’s important to note that Google has recently declared the end of Universal Analytics. As of July 1, 2023, it will no longer process new data. This means that your time to migrate to Google Analytics 4 is limited, making it your only option. To learn how to add Google Analytics code to Magento 2, check out our guide above. And for more information on this transition, you can visit this site.

Step 2: Set up a Property in Google Analytics

  • Create a property in Google Analytics for each website you want to collect data for.
  • After creating a property, your Google Analytics ID will be generated for future setup.
  • Follow instructions from Google.

You will be redirected to the Tracking ID page. Copy the Tracking ID for use in the configuration step.

Step 3: Add Google Analytics Code to Magento 2

  • Log in to the Admin panel of your store and go to Stores → Configuration.
  • Scroll down the configuration page and click on Google API under the SALES tab.
  • In the Google Analytics section, select Yes from the Enable drop-down menu, enter the Tracking ID from Step 1 in the Account Number field, and select Yes from the Enable Content Experiments drop-down menu.
  • Click on Save Config.

Step 4: Enable Ecommerce Tracking for Google Analytics

  • In the Admin area of Google Analytics, click on Ecommerce Settings.
  • Enable E-commerce and Enhanced E-commerce Reporting.
  • Click on Submit.

And you’re done! Check your store traffic activity in Google Analytics by visiting your store and then your Google Analytics account.

Final Thoughts

In conclusion, integrating Google Analytics into your Magento 2 store is an essential aspect of monitoring and tracking your store’s traffic and conversion rate. This article provided a detailed step-by-step guide on how to add Google Analytics code to Magento 2, allowing you to gain valuable insights into your website’s performance. Remember, a well-designed and functional eCommerce website is also crucial for the success of your online store. If you are yet to set up your Magento 2 store, you might also want to know How to Install Extension in Magento 2 Manually.

nodes.content:
How to Configure Magento 2 Customer Accounts: Making the customer experience on your website seamless is crucial and can’t be overemphasized. If you want to encourage repeat visits to your website, it’s essential to make it user-friendly. One crucial aspect of client interactions on a website is through the customer account. Magento 2 provides a range of configuration settings that can help simplify engagement and manage customer account options. If you’re wondering how to enable customer accounts in Magento 2, this article will guide you through each step, despite the many options available in Magento.

How to Configure Magento 2 Customer Accounts for a Seamless User Experience

Although Magento offers numerous options, the overall process may appear complex. Nevertheless, we will provide a comprehensive guide in this article to assist you through all the necessary steps.

To configure customer accounts in Magento 2, proceed to Stores > Configuration > Customers > Customers Configuration. As you can observe, there are several sections that you need to complete.

Managing Account Sharing Options

For those who run multiple websites and stores, setting the scope for customer account-sharing options is important.

In the “Share Customer Accounts” field, select one of two options:

  • Global – customer account information is shared across all websites and stores.
  • Per Website – customer account information is specific to a single website.

Online Customer Option Configuration

To optimize the client experience on your Magento 2 website, it’s essential to configure the customer options. These configurations are available in the Magento 2 Customer Configurations section of your admin panel. To ensure efficient and convenient customer sessions on your website, complete the “Online Customer Options” section.

In the “Online Customer Options” section, you can define the interval for online client activity by setting the “Online Minutes Interval” field. This determines how long the Client’s online activity is no longer accessible from the admin panel (15 minutes is the default value). If you want to apply the default value, leave the field empty.

Another important setting in this section is the “Customer Data Lifetime” field, where you can enter the number of minutes that must pass before any unsaved client data expires (the default is 60 minutes). You can adjust this value according to your specific needs.

Configuring Account Creation Options

The “Create New Account Options” section allows you to manage the options necessary for creating an account on your website.

Password Configuration

Strong passwords are essential for Client and admin accounts alike. To enhance data security, carefully configure password options.

Account Information Settings

Customers often need to change their email and/or password, so email templates should be configured accordingly.

  • Select the “Change Email Template” for Clients who want to modify their email addresses.
  • Set the “Change Email and Password Template” for clients who want to change both their email and password.

Note: Like other Magento emails, these email templates can be customized to include relevant information.

Configuring Name and Address Options

Expand the options available during account creation by configuring the Name and Address Options. There are many fields to set, but our customer name and address options guide will assist you in this process.

Login Settings

When configuring Magento customer accounts, don’t forget to consider login options, as they can impact the Client experience.

Select “Yes” or “No” in the “Redirect Customer to Account Dashboard after Logging in” to determine whether the Client will be directed to the dashboard page or continue shopping after logging in.

Address Display Configuration

Navigate to the Address Templates section to set up the display format of addresses in various documents like invoices, credit memos, and shopping carts.

  • In the Text field, input the variables used for all printed addresses.
  • Specify the order of addresses in the shopping cart’s address book list by entering variables in the Text One Line field.
  • Define the order of address fields in the Customer Addresses section of the admin panel by filling out the HTML field.
  • Determine the display of billing and shipping addresses in printed documents like invoices, shipments, and credit memos by adding variables to the PDF field.

CAPTCHA Configuration

Enhance the security of your store with Magento CAPTCHA, a tool that prevents spam and blocks brute-force attacks. Follow these steps to configure CAPTCHA for customer accounts:

  • Enable CAPTCHA on the storefront by selecting Yes in the corresponding field.
  •  Choose the font to be applied for CAPTCHA.
  •  Specify the forms for which you want to use CAPTCHA.
  • Set the Displaying Mode.
  • Enter the number of unsuccessful login attempts after which the account will be locked.
  • Specify the time for CAPTCHA to expire in the CAPTCHA Timeout (minutes) field.
  • Enter the number of symbols that make up the CAPTCHA, with the highest value being 8, or set a range (e.g. 3-6).
  • Input the symbols used in CAPTCHA, which can be letters (upper and lower case) and/or numbers (0-9).
  • Choose whether CAPTCHA characters are case-sensitive by selecting Yes or No in the Case Sensitive field.

Once you have configured all the necessary settings for Magento 2 customer accounts, it’s crucial to save your changes by clicking the Save Config button. This may take some time, but it’s necessary to ensure that the account creation and login process is convenient for both you and your clients. If you’re unsure how to configure Magento 2 customer accounts, be sure to follow the guidelines outlined in this article to optimize your Client experience.

nodes.content:
How to Move Magento 2 from Localhost to Server? In this guide, we will show you the steps involved in How to Transfer Magento 2 from Localhost to server, so you can make your online store accessible to the public. Whether you’re developing your store for the first time or migrating an existing one, moving Magento 2 from localhost to server can be a complex process. However, by following the instructions carefully, you can ensure a smooth and successful transition of your store from a local development environment to a live website.

How to Move Magento 2 from Localhost to Server: A Comprehensive Guide

Step 1: Exporting the Database from Localhost

  • Connect to your local host platform (such as XAMPP or WAMP) and log in to phpMyAdmin.
  • Locate the database for your store.
  • On the top menu, click “Export” and then hit the “Go” button.
  • Download the database file as a .sql extension or save it as a .zip file.

Step 2: Zipping Magento Files

  • Select all the files and folders from localhost.
  • Navigate to the htdocs folder (if using XAMPP) or the www folder (if using WAMP).
  • Go to the Magento folder and compress the files into a zip format.

Step 3: Uploading Magento Files to the Web Server

  • To upload the database, use cPanel on your website server.
  • Log in to cPanel.
  • Access phpMyAdmin.
  • Create a new database by clicking the “New” button.
  • Remember the database name, username, and password for future reference.

Step 4: Importing the Database

After creating the database, import the database file from Step 1.

There are two methods for importing the database:

  • Method 1: Command Line (using the following command: mysql -p -u username database_name < backup_file.sql)
  • Method 2: phpMyAdmin (by accessing the “Import” option on the top menu, selecting the .sql file, and clicking “Choose File”).

Step 5: Uploading Magento Files

You can choose to create a subfolder for a new domain or use the normal directory.

  • Upload the zip file created in Step 2 and extract it.

Step 6: Updating the env.php File for New Database Access:

  • After uploading and extracting the zip folder, access the app/etc/env.php file.
  • In the env.php file, update the information for the new database created on your domain. This includes the username, name, and password used during the import process.
  • Look for the appropriate location in the file to make these changes.

Step 7: Finding the New Domain Name for Magento

  • Save the changes made in Step 6.
  • If you need to edit the file, upload it again to the correct directory.
  • In the Magento database, go to the Table Core_Config_Data.
  • Replace the localhost URL with the domain name in the “web/unsecure/base_url

Step 8: Running Commands

To access your store, run the following commands:

php bin/magento setup:upgrade

php bin/magento setup:static-content:deploy -f

php bin/magento cache:flush

php bin/magento cache:clean

Congratulations! You now know How to Move Magento 2 from Localhost to Server successfully moved your Magento 2 store from localhost to server.

Conclusion

If you’re wondering how to move Magento 2 from localhost to server, you can follow these steps to successfully transfer your online store from a local development environment to a web server. These steps include exporting the database from localhost, uploading the files and the database to the web server, updating the env.php file for new database access, finding the new domain name for your site, and running commands to access your store. By completing these steps, you can ensure a smooth and successful transition of your store from a local environment to a live website. If you are new to it and are looking for a guide on How to Install Magento 2, this process can help you understand the steps involved in setting up a store on a server.
